translated: Description. The teaching for the Fierce Crow Goddess. The text is framed as a dialogue between Kakacandeshvari, also called Kakachamunda, who is equated with Kankali the skeleton and Kalaratri, the dark night, both forms of Kali. She is the consort Umadevi of the five-headed Bhairava, who is probably with Svacchandabhairava, who in some of his aspects is a medicine god. They are seated on Mount Kailas. After imploring him for the knowledge that leads to liberation, the god, promising to do so, teaches the preparation of herbs for healing and magic, focusing especially on the magical preparation of alchemical mercury, making this an important unpublished work on Indian alchemy.
